results.title: Oranges and lemons
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Margot Lethlean
results.brief_description: A documentary on the early education of aboriginal children. It looks at a special pre-school program to help prepare aboriginal children for school, which has been set up in Dareton, Victoria. It suggests that in the face of insensitive attitudes, conventional education will further undermine aboriginal culture.

results.title: Orange and blue
results.creator_credit: Contemporary Films, Harvard Film Service, Harvard University, Peter Chermayeff and Jane Chermayeff
results.brief_description: Two coloured balls embark on an adventure as they travel through rural and industrial settings. The skilled animation and complimentary soundtrack gives the balls entertaining personalities. Music by Joseph Raposos.

results.title: Orange
results.brief_description: Nature’s element - the movements of sun, clouds, light and shadows play the leading roles in this film. We witness the virth of a day when the first glow of morning grows to a blinding red of boiling clouds. Into this primordial atmosphere intrudes man’s machines, aeroplanes - nature rebels with explosive holocaust. Made with the assistance of the Creative Development Branch of the Australian Film Commission.

results.title: Oral language development: views of five teachers (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Louise Henry, Veriation Films, KTEH-TV (Television station : San Jose, Calif.), Channel 54 and David Espar
results.brief_description: Suggests methods for improving or maintaining the quality of reading programs. Depicts teachers working with children in an environment which provides maximum opportunity for oral language exposure and interaction. Suitable for tertiary/teacher level.

results.title: Oral hygiene: Johnnie and the D.K. robot
results.creator_credit: Larkin Studios and Film Producers Guild
results.brief_description: The importance of brushing teeth before going to bed, told in a dream which involves a little boy, a trip into space, and a D.K. Robot. On the planet Yum-Yum where sweets grow on trees, the children lose their teeth until Johnnie introduces them to toothbrushes and toothpaste. Animation and live footage.
results.title_for_label: Oral hygiene: Johnnie and the D.K. robot

results.title: Opus: impressions of British art and culture
results.creator_credit: James Archibald, British Information Services and Don Levy
results.brief_description: An impressionistic survey of the arts in Britain ranging from sculptors and painters at work to a display of Mary Quant fashions and vistas of modern architecture. The theatre is represented by excerpts from three plays staged by the Royal Shakespeare Company and there is a sequence from a new ballet by Sir Frederick Ashton. Some of the work of Henry Moore is seen as well as paintings by Francis Bacon. Includes a brief appearance by a very young Googie Withers.
results.title_for_label: Opus: impressions of British art and culture
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Archibald, British Information Services and Don Levy

results.title: Opus 65
results.creator_credit: A V Curtice, Wallace Productions, Ford Motor Company and John Taylor
results.brief_description: An attempt at discovering and expressing a relationship between music and a mechanical process on an abstract level. Richard Arnell was commissioned by the Ford Motor Company to compose a symphonic piece inspired by a visit to their factory. The scriptwriter then wrote a detailed scenario to fit the music, drawing a sketch of every set-up. The resulting film, following the scheme of the music, falls into three movements: The first, a general impression; the second, with the motive of Man versus Machine; the third, climaxing in the actual production of a car.
results.creator_credit_for_label: A V Curtice, Wallace Productions, Ford Motor Company and John Taylor
